title: oncussion in sport
intro: Some sports, the so-called ‘full-contact’ sports like rugby, American football and boxing can be dangerous. Now, the truth about the long-term effects on players who make a career taking heavy tackles or punches to the head is being slowly revealed. Neil and Georgina talk about the topic and teach you related vocabulary along the way.
this_week_question: Boxing is one of the most dangerous sports, and so my quiz question is about a famous boxer. Born in 1949, this boxer has remained mentally and physically fit despite years of punishment in the boxing ring. But who am I talking about?
a) Muhammad Ali b) George Foreman c) Mike Tyson
Listen to the programme to find out the answer.

vocab.desc: a type of traumatic brain injury caused by a bump or blow to the head
bad or worse than usual; below the usual standard
try to return to normality after a crisis or collapse
very happy and cheerful, intelligent, and full of energy
supply of something that is kept and stored for future use

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Hello. This is 6 Minute English from BBC Learning English. I’m Neil.

transcript.author: Georgina
transcript.text: And I’m Georgina.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: When it comes to sport, there’s something for everyone. Do you play a sport, Georgina?

transcript.author: Georgina
transcript.text: I used to play in a netball team years ago. Now I go jogging and I enjoy swimming too.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Yes, I go jogging sometimes and I play football, although I’m no Ronaldo!

transcript.author: Georgina
transcript.text: But some sports, the so-called ‘full contact’ sports like rugby, American football and boxing are much more dangerous. Now, the truth about the long-term effects on players who make a career taking heavy tackles or punches to the head is being slowly revealed.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And the issue of safety in sport was back in the news again recently when Danish footballer, Christian Eriksen, collapsed on the pitch during the 2020 European football championship.

transcript.author: Georgina
transcript.text: At the centre of the debate are worries about possible brain damage and dementia caused by concussion - that’s a type of traumatic brain injury caused by a bump or blow to the head and the topic of this programme.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Boxing, of course, is one of the most dangerous sports, and so my quiz question is about a famous boxer. Born in 1949, this boxer has remained mentally and physically fit despite years of punishment in the boxing ring. But who am I talking about? Is he: a) Muhammad Ali b) George Foreman?, or c) Mike Tyson?

transcript.author: Georgina
transcript.text: I’m not a big boxing fan, Neil, but I’ll say b) George Foreman.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: OK, Georgina, we’ll find out the answer to that question later in the programme.

transcript.author: Georgina
transcript.text: So far, we’ve been talking about heavy full-contact sports like boxing, but the truth is that any sportsperson can get concussed.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: In 2018 hockey player and Olympic gold medallist, Nicola White was involved in a heavy collision with another player during a warm-up match.

transcript.author: Georgina
transcript.text: Here’s Nicola telling her story to Paul Connolly, presenter of BBC World Service programme, The Inquiry:

transcript.author: Nicola White
transcript.text: I started suffering headaches, nausea, light sensitivity, noise sensitivity, my balance was off, I just felt terrible. I always used to describe it like I was in Alice in Wonderland, I just felt in such a warped world, it just felt relentless, and it never stopped.

transcript.author: Paul Connolly
transcript.text: Three years on from that moment of impact, Nicola is still picking up the pieces. Despite seeking advice and treatment from specialists in the field of head trauma, many of her symptoms persist.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: After the collision, Nicola‘s balance was off . When something is off , it’s worse than usual.

transcript.author: Georgina
transcript.text: And off can also mean ‘bad’, as in ‘this milk smells awful – it’s gone off !’

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Nicola felt terrible and her world was warped - strange and unpleasant.

transcript.author: Georgina
transcript.text: In fact, three years after the accident, she was still picking up the pieces - trying to return to normality after a crisis or collapse.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Concussion is a problem in many sports - even those like hockey or athletics that are not considered ‘full contact’.

transcript.author: Georgina
transcript.text: But the dangers involved with boxing are far greater. In fact, it’s one of the few sports that has concussion written into the rules.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Yes, that’s right. When a boxer is knocked down, he has ten seconds to stand up and get his senses together – if he can’t, there’s a good chance he’s concussed.

transcript.author: Georgina
transcript.text: Tris Dixon is a former boxer turned sportswriter. Here he is speaking to BBC World Service programme, The Inquiry, about concussion in boxing. See if you can spot the answer to the quiz question Neil asked earlier:

transcript.author: Tris Dixon
transcript.text: When you look back through history and you see that Henry Armstrong, Sugar Ray Robinson, Muhammad Ali, Joe Louis all suffered with neurological problems as they got older… but what we also need to find out is why can you have a fighter like George Foreman, who’s now in his seventies, and is as bright as a button after two long hard careers. Why do some people seem to have a reserve that has kept them safe later in life?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Tris mentions some famous boxers who suffered neurological problems in later life… and another boxer who’s still as bright as a button – an expression used to describe someone who’s happy, cheerful, intelligent, and full of energy.

transcript.author: Georgina
transcript.text: It seems that some people have a reserve – a supply of energy they keep stored up for use in the future, when it’s needed.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: OK, Georgina, let’s get back to my quiz question – I’m pretty sure you know the answer now?

transcript.author: Georgina
transcript.text: Yes, I think so. Neil asked me which famous boxer, born in 1949, was still mentally alert despite many years of fighting. I guessed it was b) George Foreman.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Good listening, Georgina!

transcript.author: Georgina
transcript.text: Thanks, Neil - looks like I’m as bright as a button today!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Let’s recap the vocabulary from this programme about concussion – atraumatic brain injury caused by a knock to the head.

transcript.author: Georgina
transcript.text: When something is off , it’s bad or worse than usual.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: The adjective warped means strange and unpleasant.

transcript.author: Georgina
transcript.text: To pick up the pieces means to try to return to the ways things were before a crisis or collapse.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: A reserve is a supply of something that you kept back until it’s needed.

transcript.author: Georgina
transcript.text: And finally, someone who’s as bright as a button is very happy and cheerful, intelligent, and full of energy!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Sounds like our 6 Minute English listeners to me!

transcript.author: Georgina
transcript.text: That’s all for our investigation into concussion in sport, but if you’d like to find out more about the subject you can listen again to the whole programme on the BBC World Service website.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And if you want to grow your brain power, not get linguistically concussed, why not join us again soon for more topical discussion and useful vocabulary here at 6 Minute English from BBC Learning English! Bye for now!

transcript.author: Georgina
transcript.text: Bye!
